author: The Telegraph
title: Where to eat in Australia
text: Aussie chefs are currently high currency on the foodie scene, with increasing numbers turning up at top restaurants around the world. Skye Gyngell and Greg Malouf boast a much-coveted Michelin star while Brett Graham, currently at London’s The Ledbury, is the only Aussie to ever hold three stars. Contemporary Australian cuisine is a healthy fusion of Asian styles and endemic produce (kangaroo, emu, mud crabs) which makes it unique. Today every major Australian city can boast cuisine to rival the best in the world. Here’s a selection of top dining venues. Melbourne Attica In a smart, brick-fronted building in the city’s Ripponlea district, Attica is rated as Australia’s number one restaurant and is the only one in the country currently to figure on the World’s 50 Best Restaurants 2015 Guide . It’s run by Ben Shewry, a gifted, inventive and occasionally wacky chef who delights in creating dishes with titles such as 142 Days On Earth. The culinary experience takes the form of five or eight degustation dishes layered with exquisite flavours. • attica.com.au Vue de monde Sitting atop the mighty Rialto tower, Vue de monde is another of Melbourne’s fine dining establishments and the jewel in the crown of chef Shannon Bennett’s restaurants (Bistro Vue, Cafe Vue). If you can get a table, you’re treated to visually extravagant dishes mixing Old and New World ingredients and cooking. • vuedemonde.com.au Queen Victoria Market Queen Victoria Market’s Food Court is packed with stalls offering cheap but very tasty street food. • qvm.com.au Sydney Quay In a city full of great restaurants, Quay continues to stand out. Aside from the fantastic view of the harbour, this much-decorated venue earns its spurs with consistently dazzling, Asian-inspired Aussie cooking from chef Peter Gilmore. • quay.com.au Rockpool Relocated to the heritage Burns And Philp building in Bridge Street, Rockpool remains one of Sydney’s top restaurants and one of the best in Australia. Chef Neil Perry oversees a modern Australian dining experience bursting with imagination and flair. There’s a sister restaurant, Rockpool Bar and Grill, in the art deco City Mutual Building in Hunter Street plus branches in Melbourne and Perth. For a less formal but still impressive foodie experience, Sydney’s food trucks allow you to enjoy great food from around the world. Download the app to track down its gourmet fleet. • rockpool.com Colourful: Adelaide Central Market sells everything from sushi to pizza Adelaide Magill Estate Vineyard Out in the city’s suburbs on the Magill Estate Vineyard you’ll find one of South Australia’s finest restaurants. Given a sleek, stylish facelift a couple of years ago, it boasts fantastic views of the Gulf Of St Vincent and some high-end dining with a distinctive Japanese twist, courtesy of chefs Scott Huggins and Emma McCaskill. The wine list, as you might imagine, is extensive. • www.magillestate.com Adelaide Central Market Adelaide’s 140-year-old Central Market is a thriving food mecca filled with 80 traders. Aside from the fantastic local produce there are numerous cafés selling everything from sushi to pizza. • adelaidecentralmarket.com.au Darwin Char An upmarket surf-and-turf restaurant with a romantic, lantern-lit patio in the historic Admiralty House. The wagyu beef and barramundi (Australia’s seabass) come highly rated. • chardarwin.com.au Mindil Beach Market Join the locals heading for Mindil Beach to catch the spectacular sunsets and enjoy some of the great food served up at the many stalls of the appropriately named Mindil Beach Sunset Market. It operates every Thursday and Sunday evening between May and October. • mindil.com.au Perth Botanical Café A new addition to the city’s dining options, the Botanical Café in Kings Park offers fantastic views out to the Swan River and the city and serves its own wine and craft ales. • botanicalcafe.com.au Fraser’s If you want to keep the view and enjoy a more upmarket experience, Fraser’s adjacent offers highly rated Western Australian cuisine. Hobart The Source Hobart’s old town is home to some excellent restaurants. Chief among them is The Source, a smart dining room perched above an art museum with great views of the Derwent River. Chef Philippe Leban oversees creative, French-inspired food using local seafood such as trumpeter, jack mackerel and ocean trout • mona.net.au Pigeon Hole Café For breakfast, the Pigeon Hole Café, a short walk west of the city centre, makes its own bread along with some delicate, tasty dishes such as jamon with caramelised onion and grana cheese. • pigeonholecafe.com.au You may also be interested in: • The best destination for food and wine • A Taste of Australia with Donna Hay • Donna Hay's caramelised chilli and salmon stir-fry recipe • Hungry for more? Tantalise your taste buds with fantastic recipes by Aussie cook Donna Hay at telegraph.co.uk/tasteofaustralia
